factoid: Pierre left the Rostóvs' with Natásha's grateful look fresh in his mind.
Pierre gazed at a comet that seemed fixed in the sky.
Pierre felt that something new was appearing on his own horizon.
The problem of the vanity and uselessness of all earthly things no longer presented itself to Pierre.
The terrible question "Why?" "Wherefore?" that had come to Pierre amid every occupation was replaced by Natásha's image.
Natásha's image replaced Pierre's terrible question.
When Pierre listened to trivial conversations, he was not horrified as formerly.
When Pierre read or heard of human baseness or folly, he was not horrified as formerly.
Pierre did not ask himself why men struggled about these things.
Pierre remembered Natásha as he had last seen her.
All Pierre's doubts vanished.
Pierre's doubts vanished because his conception of Natásha transferred him instantly to another realm.
The realm is a brighter realm of spiritual activity.
In that realm, no one could be justified or guilty.
That realm is a realm of beauty and love.
That realm is worth living for.
Pierre said to himself: "Supposing N. N. has swindled the country and the Tsar, and the country and the Tsar confer honors upon him, what does that matter?"
Pierre said: "She smiled at me yesterday and asked me to come again."
Pierre said: "I love her."
Pierre said: "No one will ever know it."
Pierre's soul felt calm and peaceful.
Pierre went into society.
Pierre drank as much as before.
Pierre led the same idle and dissipated life.
Pierre spent hours at the Rostóvs'.
Pierre had other hours he had to spend.
The habits and acquaintances Pierre had made in Moscow formed a current that bore him along irresistibly.
More disquieting reports came from the seat of war.
Natásha's health began to improve.
Natásha no longer aroused in Pierre the former feeling of careful pity.
An ever-increasing restlessness that Pierre could not explain took possession of Pierre.
Pierre felt that his condition could not continue long.
Pierre felt a catastrophe was coming that would change his whole life.
Pierre impatiently sought everywhere for signs of that approaching catastrophe.
Pierre's brother Masons revealed to Pierre a prophecy concerning Napoleon drawn from the Revelation of St. John.

In Revelation chapter 13 verse 18, it says: "Here is wisdom. Let him that hath understanding count the number of the beast: for it is the number of a man; and his number is Six hundred threescore and six."
In Revelation chapter 13 verse 5, it says: "And there was given unto him a mouth speaking great things and blasphemies; and power was given unto him to continue forty and two months."
